problem: Prove that if n is an integer and n² is odd, then n is odd.

A man lives on the 10th floor of a building. Every morning he takes the elevator down to the ground floor to go to work. When he returns in the evening, he takes the elevator to the 7th floor and walks up the stairs to reach his apartment on the 10th floor. However, on rainy days and when there are other people in the elevator, he goes directly to the 10th floor. Why does he do this?
A woman has two sons who were born on the same day of the same month of the same year to the same mother and father. But they are not twins. How is this possible?

A man is found dead in a circular room with no windows and only one door, which is locked from the inside. The room is completely empty except for a puddle of water and a small hole in the ceiling. How did he die?

You are in a room with three light switches, each connected to a light bulb in another room. You cannot see the light bulbs from where the switches are. You can flip the switches as many times as you want, but once you enter the room with the light bulbs, you cannot return to the switches. How do you determine which switch controls which light bulb?

A father and his son are in a car accident. The father dies on the scene, but the son is rushed to the hospital. At the hospital, the surgeon looks at the boy and says, 'I can't operate on this boy. He's my son.' How is this possible?

A rope is tied around the Earth at the equator, lying flat against the ground. If you add 1 meter to the length of the rope and space it evenly all the way around, how far off the ground will the rope be?

Two people enter a bar. They both order the same drink. One person drinks it slowly and survives. The other drinks it quickly and dies. The drinks were identical and weren't poisoned. What were they drinking?
A man walks into a restaurant, orders albatross soup, takes one taste, and then kills himself. Why?
A woman gives a beggar 50 cents. The woman is the beggar's sister, but the beggar is not the woman's brother. How is this possible?

A man is sitting in a pub feeling rather poor. He sees the man next to him pull out a wallet full of money. He decides to steal the wallet. He waits for the man to leave, then follows him out of the pub. Ten minutes later he returns to the pub with a satisfied smile on his face. Why doesn't he have the wallet?
You're in a dark room with a candle, a wood stove, and a gas lamp. You only have one match. What do you light first?
A man stood on one side of a river, his dog on the other. The man called his dog, who immediately crossed the river without getting wet and without using a bridge or a boat. How did the dog do it?
A man pushed his car until he reached a hotel, at which point he realized he was bankrupt. What happened?
A woman had two sons who were born on the same hour of the same day of the same year. But they were not twins and they were not adopted. How could this be?
A window cleaner is cleaning the windows on the 25th floor of a skyscraper when he slips and falls. He has no safety equipment and nothing to break his fall, but he is not hurt. How is this possible?
A girl who was just learning to drive went down a one-way street in the wrong direction, but didn't break the law. How is this possible?
There is a house with four walls. Each wall faces south. A bear walks by the house. What color is the bear?
A truck driver is going down a one-way street the wrong way, and passes at least ten police officers. None of them stop him. Why not?

A boat has a ladder that has 5 rungs. The distance between each rung is 20 cm. The bottom rung is 20 cm from the water level. The tide rises at 15 cm per hour. How long will it take for the water to reach the top rung?

A murderer is condemned to death. He has to choose between three rooms. The first is full of raging fires, the second is full of assassins with loaded guns, and the third is full of lions that haven't eaten in 3 years. Which room should he choose?

Every day, a man crosses the border from Mexico into the United States on a bicycle, carrying a bag of sand. The customs officer checks the bag, finds nothing but sand, and lets him through. Weeks later, the officer discovers the man has been smuggling something. What was he smuggling?

A man is trapped in a room. The room has only two possible exits: two doors. Through the first door, there is a room constructed from magnifying glass. The blazing hot sun instantly fries anything or anyone that enters. Through the second door, there is a fire-breathing dragon. How does the man escape?
A man is found hanging dead from the ceiling in a locked room with a puddle of water beneath him. There is no furniture in the room. How did he kill himself?
A man kills his wife, then goes into his house and has a meal. Later, the police come, and he freely admits to the murder, but they can't arrest him. Why not?
A woman shoots her husband, then holds him underwater for five minutes. Next, she hangs him. Right after, they enjoy a lovely dinner. How is this possible?
You are given 8 balls. 7 of them weigh the same, and 1 of them weighs slightly more. How can you find the ball that is heavier by using a balance and only 2 weighings?
A man walks into a bar and asks for a glass of water. The bartender pulls out a gun and points it at him. The man says 'Thank you' and walks out. What happened?
A prisoner is told, 'If you tell a lie, we will hang you and if you tell the truth, we will shoot you.' What can the prisoner say to save himself?
A man orders a meal in a restaurant and when it arrives, he says 'I can't eat this!' Then he leaves without eating or paying. Yet the waiter is not upset and the man has done nothing wrong. Why?
Two mothers and two daughters went out to eat. Everyone ate one burger, yet only three burgers were eaten in total. How is this possible?
A woman enters a library and asks for a book about Pavlov's dogs and Schrödinger's cat. The librarian says, 'It rings a bell, but I'm not sure if it's there or not.' Why is this funny?
A man and his wife race through a door, and the man comes in first. But the wife arrives before her husband. How is this possible?
A man took a picture of his son. How is it possible that his son has been deceased for over 100 years?
A man in a small town married 20 different women from the same town. All of them are still living and he never divorced any of them. Yet he broke no laws. How is this possible?
You are in a room with no doors or windows. The only things in the room are a table and a mirror. How do you get out?
A woman gave birth to two boys on the same day in the same year, but they weren't twins. How is this possible?
A perfectly cylindrical hole is drilled straight through the center of a sphere. The hole is 6 inches long. What is the volume of the remaining portion of the sphere?
Three doctors said that Bill is their brother. Bill says he has no brothers. Who is telling the truth?

A man is found dead on a Sunday morning. His wife calls the police immediately. The police question the wife and staff. The wife said she was asleep, the cook was cooking breakfast, the gardener was picking vegetables, the maid was cleaning, and the butler was getting the mail. The police immediately arrested the killer. Who was it?

A man and his son are in a car crash. The father dies at the scene and the son is rushed to the hospital. At the hospital, the surgeon looks at the boy and says 'I can't operate on this boy, he's my son.' How can this be?
When Bob entered the room, he felt instant dread. There were 53 bicycles and calendars on the wall. What profession does Bob have?
A man is facing east. He turns 90 degrees to his right, then another 180 degrees to the right, and then 90 degrees to his left. In which direction is he facing now?

Two women apply for a job. They are identical in appearance, background, and experience. The manager hires one and rejects the other. This is not discrimination. Why did the manager choose one over the other?
A man builds a rectangular house. All four sides have a southern exposure. A bear walks by. What color is the bear?
Five pieces of coal, a carrot, and a scarf are lying on the lawn. Nobody put them on the lawn, but there is a perfectly logical reason why they are there. What is it?
Without using a calculator, determine which is greater: 50^99 or 99^50?
Two boxers are in a match scheduled for 12 rounds. One of the boxers gets knocked out after 6 rounds, yet no man throws a punch. How is this possible?
A man leaves a motel, goes to his car, and honks the horn. Why did he do that?
A woman was born in 2020, but in 2023 she turned 25. How is this possible?
You enter a dark room. You have one match. There is a candle, an oil lamp, and a wood-burning stove in the room. Which one do you light first?
A man is washing windows on a high-rise building when he slips and falls. He is not wearing a safety harness and nothing breaks his fall, yet he survives without any injuries. How?

You have a drawer with 10 blue socks and 10 black socks mixed up. It is completely dark, and you need a matching pair. What is the minimum number of socks you need to take out to ensure you have a matching pair?
A man is standing outside a building. He jumps from the building's 50th floor but survives with no injuries. How is this possible?

A woman buys a brand new car, drives it for 100 miles, then sells it. The person who buys it drives it for another 100 miles before selling it back to the original dealer. When the dealer checks the odometer, it reads 0 miles. How is this possible?

You're in a completely dark room with no windows. You have 3 identical-looking light bulbs in the room, but only 1 of them works. You also have 3 light switches outside the room, and each controls 1 bulb. You can do anything with the switches before entering the room, but once you enter, you cannot leave. How can you determine which switch controls the working bulb?
A man finds something in his pocket. He throws it away. Later, he needs the item but doesn't have a replacement. Yet he manages to meet his need. What did he throw away?

A bank robber pulls out a gun and demands money from the teller. The teller says, 'You can't fool me. I know that gun isn't real.' The robber replies, 'You're right, the gun isn't real, but the robbery is.' Nevertheless, the teller still hands over the money. Why?
A man decides to step outside his house for the first time in 30 years. When he does, he immediately dies. Why?
A woman buys 10 fish. Why are only 8 alive when she gets home?
A woman has seven children, all born in different parts of the world, on different days of the week, and at different times of day. Every one was born on February 29th. How is this possible?
A man drinks from a coconut drink and dies a few hours later. The drink wasn't poisoned, and there's no fatal illness. How did he die?

A farmer challenges an engineer, a physicist, and a mathematician to fence off the largest amount of area using the least amount of fence. The engineer makes a circular fence. The physicist makes a fence that goes around the equator. The mathematician wins. What did the mathematician do?
Two people, Maria and John, were born on the same day of the same month of the same year, to the same mother and father. But they are not twins. How is this possible?
A man went to a party and drank some of the punch. He then left early. Everyone else at the party who drank the punch subsequently died of poisoning. Why did the man not die?

A man lying dead in a field still has a bullet in his head. There are no powder marks on his clothing or body, nor any sign of having been shot at from close range, and no one heard a shot. How did he die?

A man is found dead in his study. He was slumped over his desk and a gun was in his hand. There was a cassette recorder on his desk. When the police played the cassette, they heard, 'I can't go on. I have nothing to live for.' Then they heard the sound of a gunshot. Based on this evidence, the police knew that the man had been murdered. How did they know?
A woman has 3 daughters. Each daughter has a brother. How many children does the woman have in total?
A woman doesn't have any sisters. She is playing cards. A spectator asks if the King in her hand is her King. She replies, 'No, he is my father's son.' Who is the King in her hand?

Five people have to cross a bridge. They all start on the same side. Each person walks at a different pace: the 1st takes 1 minute to cross, the 2nd takes 2 minutes, the 3rd takes 5 minutes, the 4th takes 8 minutes, and the 5th takes 10 minutes. It's night and they only have one flashlight between them. The bridge is too dangerous to cross without the flashlight, and it's only wide enough for two people at a time. When two people cross, they must walk at the slower person's pace. What is the minimum time required for all five to cross the bridge?

Robert and David were on a boat. Robert fell off, but David didn't notice that Robert was missing for a full hour. When he finally noticed, he went straight to the captain. The captain responded, 'We'll turn around. He's probably a few miles behind us now.' Sure enough, they found Robert a few miles back, treading water. How did the captain know where to find Robert?
During what month do people sleep the least?
You're in a car with a canine police officer traveling at 100km/h. A truck in front of you is going at 90km/h, and you're tailgating it. How fast is the dog going?
A woman went to the bank, but she didn't want to run out of money so she went in carefully. What was her name?
A girl is at a funeral. A guy comes up to her and they talk. She's interested, but he leaves without getting her number. She's desperate to find him, so she kills her sister. Why?
What can you put in a wooden box that would make it lighter? The more of them you put in the box, the lighter it becomes.

The only entrance to a large room is through a small door that is 5 feet high. Inside the room is a huge giraffe. The giraffe is much taller than 5 feet, and the room is sealed except for the door. How did the giraffe get into the room?
I am always hungry, I must always be fed. The finger I touch will soon turn red. What am I?

A man is sitting in a pub feeling rather poor. He sees the man next to him pull out a wallet full of money. He decides to steal the wallet. He waits for the man to leave, then follows him out of the pub. Ten minutes later he returns to the pub with a satisfied smile on his face. Why doesn't he have the wallet?
A man enters a museum, sees a painting, and immediately begins to cry, saying, 'That's the most horrible thing I've ever seen!' What's going on?

A father and his son are in a horrific car accident that kills the father. The son is rushed to the hospital and ready for immediate surgery. The surgeon enters the room, looks at the patient, and says, 'I can't operate on this boy. He's my son.' How can this be?
What is the beginning of eternity, the end of time and space, the beginning of every end, and the end of every race?
A woman leaves home, turns left three times, and then returns home where she finds a man in a mask. Who is the man?

A woman is attending her mother's funeral. While there, she meets a man she has never seen before and falls in love with him at first sight. However, she forgets to ask for his name or number. A few days later she kills her sister. Why?
A man was outside taking a walk when it began to rain. The man didn't have an umbrella or a hat. His clothes got soaked, yet not a hair on his head got wet. How could this happen?

A man is driving down a country lane, when he sees a rooster sitting in the middle of the road. He slams on his brakes but still hits the rooster. The man feels terrible about what has happened. He grabs the rooster, puts it in his car, and drives to a farm he saw a mile back. He knocks on the door of the farmhouse and says, 'I'm terribly sorry, but I'm afraid I've just run over your rooster.' The woman at the door smiles and says, 'Oh, that's not our rooster. Our rooster doesn't lay eggs.' What's going on?

A man is traveling across the country. One evening, he checks into a hotel and is assigned to Room 107. At 2:00 AM, there's a knock on the door, and the hotel manager urgently asks him to move to Room 105. The man quickly relocates without asking why. The next morning, he sees several police cars at the hotel and learns that the guest in Room A was found dead. Why was the man moved from Room 107 to Room 105?

A man is discovered dead in a park. Clutched in his hand is a piece of paper. The police are called and they open the dead man's hand, revealing the piece of paper, which has written on it: '35, 118, 60, 165, 29, 131, 85, 131, 85, 7, 6, 139'. What does the series of numbers mean?
A man is found dead in a field. The only thing with him is an unopened package. How did he die?
A red house is made of red bricks, a blue house is made of blue bricks, a yellow house is made of yellow bricks. What is a greenhouse made of?

There's a man found dead in a circular mansion. The detective interviews the cook, maid, and gardener. The cook says 'I was preparing the meal.' The maid says 'I was dusting the corners.' The gardener says 'I was watering the plants.' The detective immediately arrests one of them. Which one and why?
I can run but never walk, have a mouth but never talk, have a head but never weep, have a bed but never sleep. What am I?
A man has 53 bicycles and needs to buy a new tire. What day is it?
Mark's mother has three children: Snap, Crackle, and who?
A man walks into a bar and asks for a glass of water. The bartender points a shotgun at him. The man says 'Thank you' and leaves. What happened?

A man lives on the 12th floor of an apartment building. Every morning he takes the elevator down to the lobby and leaves the building. In the evening, he gets into the elevator, and if there are other people in the elevator, he goes back to his floor directly. However, if he is alone in the elevator, he goes to the 10th floor and walks up two flights of stairs to his apartment. Why does he do this?
A woman walks into a room with a match, strikes it, and lights a cigarette. She then holds the still-burning match under a curtain, but the curtain doesn't catch fire. Why not?
How can you take 9 from 6 and get 6?

During a recent census, a man told the census taker that he had three children. When asked their ages, he replied, 'The product of their ages is 36, and the sum of their ages equals my house number.' The census taker walked outside, looked at the house number, and then said, 'I still need more information.' The man replied, 'Oh, I forgot to tell you that my oldest child likes strawberry pudding.' The census taker then knew all the children's ages. How old are they?
A boy and a doctor were fishing. The boy is the doctor's son but the doctor is not the boy's father. How can this be possible?
Why do Chinese men eat more rice than Japanese men?

A farmer noticed that when she plays classical music in her greenhouse, her tomato plants produce 20% more fruit. She concludes that classical music causes tomato plants to be more productive. What alternative explanations might explain this correlation without classical music being the direct cause of increased productivity?

After a city installed more streetlights, crime rates decreased by 15%. City officials claimed that the streetlights deterred criminal activity. What are other possible explanations for this observed decrease in crime that might not involve the streetlights directly causing the reduction?

A pharmaceutical company conducted a study where 100 patients with headaches were given a new drug. 80% reported their headaches disappeared within 30 minutes. The company concludes their drug effectively treats headaches. What critical factors are missing in this analysis to establish causation?

Studies show that children who sleep with a night light are more likely to develop nearsightedness later in life. Does this mean night lights cause nearsightedness? What other causal explanation might account for this correlation?

A marketing team observes that ice cream sales and drowning deaths both increase during summer months. Explain why it would be fallacious to conclude that ice cream consumption causes drowning, and identify the likely common cause creating this correlation.

In a controlled experiment, plants were divided into two groups. Group A was exposed to jazz music for 4 hours daily, while Group B received no music. After 6 weeks, Group A plants were 15% taller. Besides music directly affecting plant growth, what confounding variables might explain this difference?

A study finds that people who drink 1-2 glasses of wine daily live longer than non-drinkers. Some media outlets report 'Wine extends your lifespan.' What factors make it difficult to establish a causal relationship between wine consumption and longevity from this correlation alone?

When a new principal took over at Lincoln High School, test scores improved by 25% over three years. The school board attributes this improvement to the principal's leadership. What other factors might actually be responsible for the improved test scores?

Countries with higher chocolate consumption per capita have more Nobel Prize winners per 10 million population. Does this mean chocolate consumption increases scientific achievement? What's a more plausible explanation for this correlation?

After a company implemented a wellness program, employee sick days decreased by 30%. The HR director claims the program improved employee health. What alternative explanations might account for the decrease in reported sick days?

In a classroom experiment, a teacher gave one group of students positive reinforcement when they answered correctly, while another group received no special treatment. The first group showed significantly higher improvement. Besides the reinforcement itself, what other mechanisms might explain this difference?

A researcher observes that neighborhoods with more trees have lower crime rates. She concludes that planting trees reduces crime. What are some alternative explanations for this correlation that don't involve trees directly causing lower crime rates?

People who eat breakfast regularly tend to have lower BMIs than those who skip breakfast. Some nutritionists claim eating breakfast causes weight control. Identify possible confounding variables that might explain this relationship without breakfast directly causing lower BMIs.

When an airline started charging for checked baggage, passenger complaints about delayed flights increased. The airline's management concluded the baggage fees were causing customer dissatisfaction. What's a more complex causal chain that might explain this relationship?

As online streaming services grew in popularity, physical media sales (CDs, DVDs) declined. While streaming seems to have caused the decline in physical media, what specific causal mechanisms might be at work in this industry transformation?

After a coastal town banned plastic bags, the number of sea turtles nesting on nearby beaches increased by 40%. Environmental groups credited the bag ban for the increase. What other factors might explain the increase in turtle nesting activity?

A psychologist noted that children who play violent video games show more aggressive behavior. The psychologist concludes that violent games cause aggression. What reverse causal explanation might equally explain this observation?

Following a major earthquake, scientists observed unusual behavior in certain animals hours before the event. Some concluded that animals can sense impending earthquakes. What methodological problems exist in establishing this causal relationship?

Hospital data showed that patients who receive more nurse visits during their stay have longer recovery times. A hospital administrator concluded that frequent nurse visits slow recovery. What's the likely actual causal relationship here?

In a factory, workers who took regular 5-minute breaks every hour produced 7% more parts per day than those who took fewer breaks. The factory owner attributes the productivity increase to reduced mental fatigue. What different causal mechanisms might explain this productivity increase?

When a university made SAT scores optional for admission, the average SAT score of enrolled students increased. The admissions director claimed this proves the optional policy attracts stronger students. What selection bias might explain this outcome instead?

A study found that people who drink four or more cups of coffee daily have a lower risk of developing Parkinson's disease. Some media reports claimed coffee prevents Parkinson's. What genetic or lifestyle factors might create this correlation without coffee being protective?

After a city reduced highway speed limits from 70 mph to 55 mph, traffic fatalities decreased by 25%. The transportation department attributed this to lower speeds causing fewer deadly accidents. What other factors related to the speed limit change might contribute to this effect?

Countries with higher social media usage rates show higher rates of depression among teenagers. Many assume social media causes depression. What bidirectional causal relationship might better explain this correlation?

A restaurant changed its menu to include calorie counts and noticed that average order totals decreased by 15%. Management attributed this to customers choosing lower-calorie options. What other causal mechanisms might explain the decrease in order totals?

A meteorologist observes that when migrating birds fly at lower altitudes, rain typically follows within 24 hours. She concludes that low-flying birds predict rain. What's the likely common cause affecting both bird flight patterns and precipitation?

Students who study in groups earn higher grades than those who study alone. An education researcher concludes that group study causes improved academic performance. What selection effects might explain this correlation without group study directly causing better grades?

In an experiment, researchers found that participants who held a warm cup of coffee judged others as having 'warmer' personalities compared to participants who held iced coffee. While the researchers claimed that physical warmth influences social perception, what methodological issues might challenge this causal conclusion?

A gym found that members who attended early morning workout sessions were more likely to maintain their membership for over a year compared to afternoon attendees. The gym concluded morning workouts increase commitment. What personality or lifestyle factors might actually explain this correlation?

When a retail store played slower tempo music, customers spent more time shopping and purchases increased by 17%. The store manager concluded slow music causes increased sales. Beyond the direct effect of music, what mediating factors might explain this causal chain?

A town installed speed cameras on a stretch of highway and observed a 40% reduction in accidents in that area. The police chief attributed this to the cameras deterring speeding. What regression to the mean effect might partially explain these results?

Researchers found that married men have better health outcomes and live longer than single men. Some journalists reported that marriage causes improved male health. What self-selection bias might be at work in this correlation?

A company implemented a four-day work week and saw productivity increase by 20%. The CEO claimed the shortened week caused employees to work more efficiently. What Hawthorne effect might be influencing these results?

Heart attack rates in a community dropped significantly after a new cardiac care center opened. Hospital administrators attributed this to improved emergency treatment. What prevention measures implemented alongside the new center might actually be driving this change?

When a delivery service introduced a customer satisfaction guarantee, returns decreased by 25%. The company concluded the guarantee gave customers more confidence in their purchases. What changes in customer or employee behavior might actually explain the decrease in returns?

Researchers found that children with night lights in their bedrooms were more likely to develop myopia (nearsightedness). They initially concluded night lights caused myopia. Later research revealed what actual causal mechanism involving genetic factors?

A study found that cities with more bicycle lanes have fewer bicycle accidents. Urban planners concluded that building bike lanes reduces accidents. What intervening variable related to cyclist behavior might explain this effect?

When a school district increased physical education time by 30 minutes daily, standardized test scores improved. Administrators claimed exercise directly enhanced cognitive performance. What changes in school schedule or student engagement might mediate this relationship?

A large observational study found that people who take multivitamins live longer than those who don't. Supplement companies cited this as evidence for the life-extending benefits of vitamins. What lifestyle confounders likely explain this correlation?

After implementing stricter attendance policies, a university saw graduation rates increase by 12%. Administrators credited the policy with improving student outcomes. What self-selection effects might be occurring here instead?

Statistics show that hospitals with larger nursing staffs have lower patient mortality rates. Hospital administrators concluded that hiring more nurses directly saves lives. What hospital characteristics might be common causes of both higher staffing and better outcomes?

A social media platform changed its algorithm to show users more content from friends and family and less from businesses. User engagement increased by 15%. The company attributed this to users preferring personal content. What novelty effect might be confounding these results?

Neighborhoods with more ice cream shops have higher crime rates. A naive analysis might suggest ice cream shops cause crime. What environmental variable likely causes both increased ice cream consumption and higher crime rates in these areas?

A study found that students who receive merit scholarships have higher college GPAs than non-scholarship students. The scholarship foundation claimed their financial support causes academic excellence. What pre-existing differences likely explain this correlation?

When a store moved expensive items from high shelves to eye level, sales of those items increased by 35%. The store manager concluded shelf placement causes purchasing decisions. What cognitive mechanisms explain this causal relationship?

As organic food sales have increased over the past decade, so have autism diagnosis rates. Some alternative health sites claim organic food consumption causes autism. Explain why this represents the post hoc ergo propter hoc fallacy.

Researchers found that people who regularly floss have better cardiovascular health than non-flossers. Dental associations suggested flossing improves heart health. What personal health habits likely serve as confounding variables in this relationship?

When a restaurant added healthier menu options, overall sales decreased by 8%. Management concluded that customers dislike healthy food. What more complex causal mechanisms might explain this sales decrease?

A city observed that neighborhoods with more trees had lower crime rates. The parks department proposed planting trees to reduce crime. What socioeconomic factors might explain both increased tree coverage and lower crime rates?

Taller people tend to earn higher salaries than shorter people. Some conclude height causes higher earning potential. What social perception factors might mediate this relationship rather than height directly causing higher pay?

After increasing the minimum wage, a state saw small business closures increase by 5%. Some economists blamed the wage increase for forcing businesses to close. What economic cycle factors might actually explain this timing coincidence?
Regions with higher cheese consumption per capita have more deaths from bedsheet entanglement. This odd correlation demonstrates what important principle about causation versus correlation?

A TV station that broadcasts more violent content has viewers who report higher levels of anxiety about crime. The station manager is accused of causing public fear. What viewer self-selection might be occurring instead of a causal relationship?

When a company implemented mandatory diversity training, reports of workplace discrimination initially increased. Some executives worried the training caused more discrimination. What reporting effect likely explains this counterintuitive result?

Studies show homeowners are more likely to vote than renters. Politicians concluded that owning property causes civic engagement. What stability and investment factors might be confounding variables in this relationship?

When a popular diet book recommended eliminating dairy, many readers reported feeling more energetic. The author claimed dairy elimination causes increased energy. What placebo and expectation effects might be operating here?

Areas with more mosquito activity report higher ice cream sales. Obviously, ice cream doesn't attract mosquitoes, and mosquitoes don't cause ice cream cravings. What third variable creates this spurious correlation?

A study found that children who received music lessons had higher math scores than those who didn't. Music educators claimed music training enhances mathematical ability. What parental investment factors might actually explain this correlation?

After implementing a zero-tolerance policy for tardiness, a school saw attendance rates decline by 7%. The principal worried the strict policy backfired. What student decision-making process might explain this causal chain?

Counties with more fast food restaurants have higher obesity rates. While fast food consumption likely contributes to obesity, what urban planning and food access issues might be common causes in this relationship?

Women who take hormone replacement therapy (HRT) were observed to have lower rates of heart disease than women who don't take HRT. Initially, doctors concluded HRT protects against heart disease. Later randomized controlled trials showed different results. What selection bias likely created the misleading initial correlation?

A software company that allowed remote work saw employee satisfaction scores increase by 22%. Leadership concluded that remote work causes higher job satisfaction. What selection effects might be occurring if only certain employees chose remote options?

Young adults who regularly attend religious services have lower rates of substance abuse than non-attendees. Religious leaders cite this as evidence that religious participation prevents substance abuse. What family and community factors might better explain this correlation?

A bakery that started opening at 6am instead of 7am saw a 25% increase in daily sales. The owner attributed this to capturing the early morning customer segment. What changes in product freshness and availability throughout the day might also contribute to this increase?

Researchers observed that children who watch more than 2 hours of television daily have lower reading scores. They concluded screen time reduces reading ability. What parental supervision factors might be the actual causal mechanism here?

A hospital noticed that patients admitted on weekends had worse outcomes than those admitted on weekdays. Administrators worried weekend care was substandard. What differences in case severity and staffing might explain this 'weekend effect'?

People who use fitness trackers tend to be more physically active than non-users. Device manufacturers claim their trackers motivate exercise. What selection bias makes it difficult to determine if trackers cause increased activity or if active people simply buy trackers?

Countries with higher chocolate consumption have more Nobel Prize winners per capita. While it's tempting to conclude chocolate enhances cognitive function, what economic development factors explain both variables?

A dating app found that users who post photos with dogs receive 30% more matches than those without dogs. The company concluded dogs make people appear more attractive. What personality traits might people be inferring from dog ownership that actually drive this effect?

When a tax was implemented on sugary drinks, consumption decreased by 20%. Health officials attributed this to the tax making sugary drinks less appealing. What price sensitivity and availability factors might better explain this causal relationship?

Children who sleep less than 9 hours per night show higher rates of behavioral problems at school. Sleep researchers concluded sleep deprivation causes behavior issues. What family environment factors might be causing both poor sleep and behavior problems?

A shipping company that implemented GPS tracking in delivery trucks saw fuel consumption decrease by 15%. Management concluded tracking caused drivers to take more efficient routes. What awareness and accountability factors might explain this causal mechanism?

People diagnosed with insomnia are more likely to develop depression later in life than those without sleep issues. Some researchers suggest insomnia causes depression. What bidirectional relationship likely exists between these conditions?

When a school district blocked social media sites on school networks, test scores increased by 5%. Administrators claimed reducing digital distractions improved learning outcomes. What implementation and measurement timing issues might affect this conclusion?

Heavy coffee drinkers have a lower risk of developing Type 2 diabetes than non-coffee drinkers. While some suggest coffee prevents diabetes, what lifestyle differences between heavy coffee drinkers and non-drinkers might explain this correlation?

Areas with more bars and liquor stores have higher crime rates. While alcohol consumption might contribute to crime, what neighborhood economic factors likely influence both alcohol outlet density and crime rates?

A website changed its font to be more readable and saw average time spent on site increase by 25%. The UX designer concluded font readability causes longer engagement. What content consumption patterns might actually explain this increase in time spent?

Smokers who use nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) are more likely to successfully quit than those who attempt to quit without aids. This suggests NRT causes higher quit success. What motivation and commitment differences might exist between those who seek NRT and those who don't?

A company found that employees who participated in their wellness program had fewer sick days than non-participants. HR concluded the wellness program improved health. What pre-existing health consciousness might explain both program participation and fewer sick days?

Students who eat breakfast before standardized tests score higher than those who don't. Nutritionists claim breakfast consumption improves cognitive performance. What socioeconomic factors might be common causes of both breakfast consumption and test performance?

Homeowners with programmable thermostats use less energy than those with manual thermostats. Energy companies concluded smart thermostats cause energy conservation. What homeowner characteristics might explain both the purchase of a programmable thermostat and energy-conscious behavior?

After introducing flexible work hours, a company saw employee turnover decrease by 28%. Management attributed this to the new policy improving work-life balance. What economic conditions in the job market might have coincidentally changed during this same period?

People who consume artificial sweeteners are more likely to be overweight than those who consume regular sugar. Some conclude artificial sweeteners cause weight gain. What reverse causality might better explain this relationship?

Countries with higher education spending per student show better academic performance on international tests. Education advocates cite this as proof that money improves educational outcomes. What cultural attitudes toward education might be confounding variables here?

Neighborhoods with more public parks have lower rates of childhood obesity. Urban planners concluded that parks cause increased physical activity and better health outcomes. What community wealth factors might explain both greater park access and lower obesity rates?

A restaurant that started displaying calorie counts on menus saw orders of high-calorie items decrease by 20%. Nutritionists concluded calorie information causes healthier food choices. What self-presentation effects might occur when people order food in the presence of others?

Cities with higher bicycle usage rates have fewer traffic fatalities per capita. Transportation officials concluded that cycling reduces deadly accidents. What urban design factors might cause both increased cycling and safer overall transportation systems?

A streaming service found that subscribers who watch documentaries are less likely to cancel their subscriptions than those who primarily watch reality TV. The company concluded documentary viewing causes subscriber loyalty. What viewer characteristics might explain both content preferences and subscription retention?

Houses with swimming pools sell for higher prices than comparable homes without pools. Real estate agents tell homeowners that adding a pool will increase their home's value. What neighborhood and economic factors might explain both pool installation and higher home values?

When airlines introduced checked baggage fees, the rate of carry-on luggage significantly increased and boarding times lengthened. While it seems baggage fees caused slower boarding, what passenger decision-making processes created this causal chain?

Plants grown under green light grow slower than plants grown under full-spectrum light. A botanist concluded green light inhibits plant growth. What property of chlorophyll and light absorption explains this causal relationship in terms of energy availability?

Children who participate in music programs have better language skills than non-participants. Music educators claim music training enhances language development. What parental involvement factors might influence both music participation and language skill development?

When a company moved from annual performance reviews to quarterly feedback sessions, employee performance ratings improved by 18%. HR concluded more frequent feedback causes better performance. What measurement and recency biases might affect this conclusion?

Older adults who engage in regular volunteer work report higher levels of life satisfaction than non-volunteers. Volunteer organizations claim helping others causes happiness. What health and mobility factors might explain who is able to volunteer in the first place?

A town that installed roundabouts to replace four-way stops saw a 35% reduction in intersection accidents. Traffic engineers concluded roundabouts cause safer driving. What changes in driver behavior and traffic flow explain this causal mechanism?

College graduates with higher GPAs tend to earn higher starting salaries. Academic advisors tell students that better grades cause better job opportunities. What underlying qualities might cause both academic success and workplace value?

A hotel that placed plants in guest rooms received higher satisfaction scores than before the renovation. Management attributed this to biophilic design enhancing guest experience. What overall renovation and modernization effects might be confounding this conclusion?

Children who are read to daily by parents develop larger vocabularies than those who aren't read to regularly. Literacy advocates claim reading to children causes vocabulary growth. What parent-child interaction factors beyond the actual reading might contribute to this language development?

After a social media platform changed its algorithm to prioritize posts with high engagement, users reported increased feelings of anxiety and inadequacy. Mental health researchers concluded the algorithm change caused psychological distress. What content selection and social comparison mechanisms explain this effect?

People who meditate regularly report lower stress levels than non-meditators. Meditation instructors claim meditation causes stress reduction. What self-selection factors might influence who chooses to establish a meditation practice in the first place?
In a class of 30 students, each student is randomly assigned to one of 5 project groups. What is the probability that exactly 7 students are assigned to group #1?
A fair six-sided die is rolled 10 times. What is the probability of getting exactly 3 sixes?
In a standard 52-card deck, what is the probability of drawing 5 cards and getting exactly 3 hearts?
A bag contains 8 red marbles, 5 blue marbles, and 7 green marbles. If you draw 4 marbles without replacement, what is the probability of drawing exactly 2 red marbles and 2 blue marbles?
Alice and Bob play a game where they take turns flipping a fair coin. The first person to flip heads wins. If Alice goes first, what is the probability that she wins the game?

A medical test for a disease has a 98% chance of correctly identifying someone who has the disease (sensitivity) and a 95% chance of correctly identifying someone who doesn't have the disease (specificity). If 2% of the population has the disease, what is the probability that a person who tests positive actually has the disease?
Three fair six-sided dice are rolled. What is the probability that the sum of the three dice is exactly 10?
In a lottery, 6 numbers are drawn from 1 to 49 without replacement. If you buy one ticket and select 6 numbers, what is the probability of matching exactly 3 of the drawn numbers?
A box contains 10 light bulbs, of which 3 are defective. If 4 bulbs are selected at random, what is the probability that at least one of them is defective?
A biased coin has a 0.6 probability of landing heads. If the coin is flipped 8 times, what is the probability of getting exactly 5 heads?
In a group of 23 people, what is the probability that at least two people share the same birthday? Assume there are 365 possible birthdays and each is equally likely.
A fair coin is flipped until either heads appears twice in a row or tails appears twice in a row. What is the expected number of flips needed?
Four cards are drawn from a standard deck without replacement. What is the probability of drawing exactly two aces?

In a certain city, it rains on 30% of days. If it rains today, there is a 70% chance it will rain tomorrow. If it doesn't rain today, there is a 20% chance it will rain tomorrow. If it's raining today, what is the probability it will be raining three days from now?
A jar contains 5 red, 3 green, and 2 blue marbles. If three marbles are drawn without replacement, what is the probability that they are drawn in the order: red, green, blue?
Five cards are drawn from a standard 52-card deck. What is the probability of getting a full house (three cards of one rank and two cards of another rank)?
A bag contains 5 red balls and 7 blue balls. Balls are drawn one by one without replacement until all balls of one color are gone. What is the probability that the last ball drawn is red?
Two fair six-sided dice are rolled. Given that the sum of the dice is at least 10, what is the probability that at least one die shows a 6?
Three points are randomly and independently chosen on the circumference of a circle. What is the probability that all three points lie on the same semi-circle?
In a series of independent trials, the probability of success in each trial is 0.3. What is the expected number of trials needed until the first success occurs?
A box contains 15 chips: 5 red, 4 blue, 3 green, and 3 yellow. You randomly select 3 chips without replacement. What is the probability that you select exactly one red chip and exactly one blue chip?
You roll a fair six-sided die repeatedly. What is the expected number of rolls needed to see all six values at least once?

In a class of 20 students, what is the probability that at least two students have the same first and last initials if each student has two initials chosen randomly from the 26 letters of the alphabet?
A standard deck of 52 cards is shuffled. What is the probability that the top card is an ace and the bottom card is a king?
Ten balls numbered 1 through 10 are placed in a bag. If three balls are drawn without replacement, what is the probability that the sum of the numbers is even?

A box contains 8 identical-looking coins, but one of them is counterfeit and lighter than the others. Using a balance scale, what is the minimum number of weighings needed to identify the counterfeit coin with certainty?

Five people enter an elevator at the ground floor of a building with 10 floors (including the ground floor). Each person randomly selects a floor to exit (other than the ground floor). What is the probability that no two people exit at the same floor?

A game show contestant is faced with three closed doors. Behind one door is a car, and behind the other two are goats. After the contestant picks a door, the host (who knows what's behind each door) opens one of the other doors to reveal a goat. The host then offers the contestant the opportunity to switch their choice to the remaining unopened door. Should the contestant switch, and what is the probability of winning the car if they do?

In a survey, 60% of respondents liked product A, 50% liked product B, and 30% liked both products. If a respondent is selected at random, what is the probability that they liked at least one of the products?
A committee of 3 people is to be randomly selected from a group of 5 men and 4 women. What is the probability that the committee has at least 2 women?

You play a game where you roll a fair six-sided die up to 3 times. After each roll, you can either stop and keep the value showing, or roll again. Once you stop or have rolled 3 times, your score is the value showing on the die. What strategy maximizes your expected score?

A room contains n people, each with a birthday on one of the 365 days of the year (ignore leap years). What is the smallest value of n such that the probability of at least two people sharing a birthday is greater than 0.5?
Three fair six-sided dice are rolled. What is the probability that the values shown form a geometric sequence?
Cards are drawn one by one from a well-shuffled standard 52-card deck. What is the expected number of cards that need to be drawn until the first ace appears?
Alice and Bob take turns tossing a fair coin. The first person to get heads wins. If Alice goes first, what is the probability that she wins?

A jar initially contains 10 red marbles and 10 blue marbles. You repeatedly draw a marble at random, observe its color, and then return it to the jar along with another marble of the same color. What is the probability that after 10 draws, there are 15 red marbles in the jar?
A standard deck of 52 cards is shuffled. What is the probability that the top 13 cards contain exactly 4 aces?
Five balls are randomly placed into five bins, with each ball independently and equally likely to be placed in any bin. What is the probability that exactly one bin remains empty?

In a city, 60% of the days are sunny, 30% are cloudy, and 10% are rainy. If it's sunny, there's a 70% chance the next day will be sunny, a 20% chance it will be cloudy, and a 10% chance it will be rainy. If it's cloudy, there's a 40% chance the next day will be sunny, a 40% chance it will be cloudy, and a 20% chance it will be rainy. If it's rainy, there's a 30% chance the next day will be sunny, a 40% chance it will be cloudy, and a 30% chance it will be rainy. If it's sunny today, what is the probability it will be rainy two days from now?
A shooter has 10 consecutive shots. For each shot, the probability of hitting the target is 0.7, independent of other shots. What is the probability of hitting the target at least 8 times?

A and B play a series of games. In each game, A wins with probability 0.6 and B wins with probability 0.4. They play until one player has won two more games than the other. What is the probability that A wins the series?
A three-digit number is formed by randomly selecting three digits from 1 to 9 without replacement. What is the probability that the number is divisible by 3?
In a certain game, you roll a fair six-sided die. If you roll a 6, you win $10. If you roll a 1, you lose $5. For any other roll, you get to roll again. What is the expected value of this game?
Three fair dice are rolled. What is the probability that the largest number shown appears exactly once?

A virus scanner has a 99% probability of detecting a virus if one is present, and a 2% probability of falsely indicating that a virus is present when none is. If 1% of all files actually contain a virus, what is the probability that a file contains a virus given that the scanner indicates a virus is present?
In a sequence of independent tosses of a fair coin, what is the expected number of tosses until the pattern HHT (heads, heads, tails) appears?
A bag contains 3 red, 4 blue, and 5 green marbles. Three marbles are drawn at random without replacement. What is the probability that marbles of all three colors are drawn?
Alice and Bob play a game with a fair coin. They take turns tossing the coin, with Alice going first. The first person to get tails wins. What is the probability that Alice wins?
A database contains 1000 records, of which 10 are corrupted. A random sample of 50 records is checked for corruption. What is the probability that exactly 2 corrupted records are found in the sample?

On a multiple-choice test with 5 questions, each question has 4 possible answers, only one of which is correct. A student knows the answer to 2 questions and guesses randomly on the other 3. What is the probability that the student answers exactly 4 questions correctly?

A bus arrives at a bus stop every 15 minutes starting at noon (so it arrives at 12:00, 12:15, 12:30, etc.). If a passenger arrives at the bus stop at a random time between 12:00 and 1:00, what is the expected waiting time for the next bus?

Ten identical balls are randomly placed into nine distinct boxes, with each ball independently placed into any box with equal probability. What is the probability that exactly one box contains exactly two balls, and no box contains more than two balls?
A four-digit PIN code uses the digits 0-9, with repetition allowed. If a thief tries four different PIN codes at random, what is the probability of successfully unlocking the device?

Two players take turns removing 1, 2, or 3 stones from a pile that initially has 20 stones. The player who takes the last stone wins. If both players play optimally, what is the probability that the first player wins?
In a game of bridge, 13 cards are dealt to each of the four players from a standard 52-card deck. What is the probability that one player receives all 13 spades?
A group of 25 people is randomly divided into 5 teams of 5 people each. If two specific individuals are in this group, what is the probability that they end up on the same team?

You have 8 coins that look identical, but one is counterfeit and lighter than the others. Using a balance scale, what is the minimum number of weighings needed to identify the counterfeit coin with certainty?
In a certain lottery, 6 numbers are drawn from the numbers 1 through 49 without replacement. What is the probability of matching at least 4 of the 6 numbers on a single ticket?
An urn contains 3 red balls and 2 green balls. Balls are drawn one at a time without replacement until all balls of one color have been drawn. What is the probability that the last ball drawn is red?
At a carnival game, you are given 5 dice. You roll all 5 dice, and if you get at least four of the same number, you win a prize. What is the probability of winning?
Alice and Bob play the following game: They take turns rolling a fair six-sided die, with Alice going first. The first person to roll a 6 wins. What is the probability that Alice wins?

A drawer contains 10 pairs of socks, with each pair being a different color. If 7 individual socks are randomly selected from the drawer, what is the probability of getting at least one matching pair?

Three people are randomly placed in a line. Independently, each person is assigned a hat that is red with probability 1/2 and blue with probability 1/2. Each person can see only the hats of the people in front of them in line. Starting from the back of the line, each person guesses the color of their own hat. What strategy maximizes the probability that at least two people guess correctly?
A biased coin lands heads with probability 0.7. If the coin is flipped repeatedly, what is the probability that the 3rd head appears on the 5th flip?

In the Monty Hall problem, you're on a game show where you're asked to choose one of three doors. Behind one door is a car, and behind the other two are goats. After you choose a door, the host (who knows what's behind each door) opens one of the other doors to reveal a goat, and then offers you the chance to switch your choice to the remaining unopened door. If you switch, what is the probability you win the car?
A box contains 6 red balls and 4 green balls. Balls are drawn one at a time without replacement until all balls of one color have been drawn. What is the expected number of draws needed?
A six-sided die is rolled repeatedly. What is the expected number of rolls until a previously rolled number appears again?
A hunter has two hunting dogs. When released, each dog independently finds the prey with probability 0.8. What is the probability that the prey is found if the hunter releases both dogs?
In a group of 7 men and 5 women, 4 people are randomly selected to form a committee. What is the probability that the committee has more women than men?
A fair six-sided die is rolled 6 times. What is the probability of rolling each number exactly once?

You have 7 keys, but only one of them opens a certain lock. You try the keys one by one, randomly and without replacement, until you find the correct key. What is the expected number of keys you will need to try?
In a class of 30 students, what is the probability that at least 3 students have the same birthday? Assume there are 365 days in a year and birthdays are uniformly distributed.
Two fair six-sided dice are rolled. Given that the sum is odd, what is the probability that at least one die shows a 3?

A jar contains 10 identical-looking coins: 6 fair coins and 4 biased coins. The biased coins come up heads with probability 0.8. A coin is selected at random from the jar and flipped 5 times, showing heads every time. What is the probability that the selected coin is biased?
A deck of 52 cards is shuffled. What is the probability that at least one of the four aces is in the top 5 cards?

In a round-robin tournament with 8 players, each player plays exactly one match against each of the other players. If each match results in a win for one player and a loss for the other (no ties), what is the probability that exactly 3 players win exactly 4 matches each?
A bin contains red, blue, and green balls in the ratio 2:3:5. If two balls are drawn at random without replacement, what is the probability that they are of different colors?

A code consists of 5 digits, each either 0 or 1. The digits are chosen randomly and independently, with probability p of choosing 1 and probability 1-p of choosing 0. If the probability of getting a code with exactly 3 ones is maximized, what is the value of p?

A jar initially contains 5 black balls and 5 white balls. Balls are drawn one at a time without replacement. What is the probability that the number of black balls drawn is never less than the number of white balls drawn?
A standard deck of 52 cards is shuffled. What is the expected number of cards that need to be turned over from the top until the first heart appears?

In a class, 70% of the students passed the midterm and 75% passed the final. If 65% of the students passed both exams, what is the probability that a student who passed the midterm also passed the final?
A box contains 20 light bulbs, of which 4 are defective. If 6 bulbs are selected at random without replacement, what is the probability that exactly 2 of them are defective?
Two players, A and B, take turns rolling a fair six-sided die. The first player to roll a 6 wins. If A goes first, what is the probability that A wins?
A sequence of fair coin tosses yields 10 heads in a row. What is the probability that the next toss will also be heads?
In a lottery, 5 numbers are drawn without replacement from the numbers 1 through 35. If you pick 5 numbers, what is the probability of matching exactly 3 of the drawn numbers?

A test for a certain disease has a false positive rate of 5% and a false negative rate of 2%. If 3% of the population has the disease, what is the probability that a person who tests positive actually has the disease?
Alice flips a fair coin 8 times and Bob flips a fair coin 10 times. What is the probability that Alice gets more heads than Bob?
In a group of 10 people, everyone shakes hands with everyone else exactly once. How many handshakes take place in total?
Three points are chosen randomly and independently on the perimeter of a circle. What is the probability that all three points lie on the same semicircle?
A factory produces components with a 0.5% defect rate. The components are shipped in boxes of 200. What is the probability that a box contains at least one defective component?
A fair coin is tossed 10 times. What is the probability of getting at least one run of at least 3 consecutive heads?
A bag contains 4 red marbles and 6 blue marbles. Marbles are drawn one at a time without replacement. What is the probability of drawing a red marble on the 5th draw?

Three shooters, A, B, and C, take part in a duel. A shoots first, then B (if still alive), then C (if still alive), then back to A, and so on. A hits the target with probability 1/3, B with probability 2/3, and C with probability 1. What strategy maximizes A's chance of survival?

A certain town has two hospitals: one large and one small. In a given day, the large hospital delivers about 45 babies, while the small one delivers about 15 babies. About 50% of all babies are boys. On a given day, which hospital is more likely to deliver at least 60% boys?
You have a biased coin that comes up heads with probability p. You want to use this coin to simulate a fair coin toss. Describe a method to do this and explain why it works.

A game consists of rolling a fair six-sided die up to three times. After each roll, you can either stop and collect points equal to the value shown, or roll again. If you roll three times, you must keep the third roll. What strategy maximizes your expected score?
In the card game of bridge, each of four players is dealt 13 cards from a standard 52-card deck. What is the probability that one player gets all 13 cards of a single suit?

A box contains 100 light bulbs, of which 10 are defective. You select bulbs one by one without replacement until you find a defective one. What is the expected number of bulbs you will need to select?

Alice and Bob play a game taking turns removing 1, 2, or 3 sticks from a pile that initially has 15 sticks. The player who takes the last stick wins. If Alice goes first and both players play optimally, what is the probability that Alice wins?

In a basketball free-throw shooting contest, player A makes each shot with probability 0.7 and player B with probability 0.8. Each player takes n shots. What is the probability that they make the same number of shots?
In a predator-prey ecosystem, when the wolf population increases, what is likely to happen to the deer population in the short term? And what subsequent effect might this have on the wolf population?

A city implements a congestion charge to reduce traffic in the downtown area. Besides reducing downtown traffic, what are two potential unintended consequences of this policy on surrounding neighborhoods?
In a supply chain, if manufacturing capacity increases by 30% but distribution capacity remains the same, what system-wide bottleneck is likely to emerge, and how might it affect overall efficiency?
A social media platform changes its algorithm to maximize user engagement. How might this change affect information diversity across the platform, and what feedback loops could emerge?
In a healthcare system, if emergency room visits are prioritized for funding and resource allocation over preventive care, what long-term effects might emerge in overall population health outcomes?
A company implements a bonus system that rewards individual performance. How might this affect collaboration and overall team productivity, and what balancing mechanism might be needed?
When antibiotics are overused in a population, what systematic changes occur in the bacterial ecosystem, and how does this create future challenges for healthcare?
In an urban water management system, what are the interconnected effects of replacing natural ground cover with impermeable surfaces like concrete and asphalt?
A government offers subsidies for corn production. Beyond increasing corn supply, how might this policy affect other agricultural products, food prices, and land use patterns?
In a software development team, if the focus shifts entirely to speed of delivery rather than code quality, what systemic problems might emerge over multiple release cycles?
A school system decides to rank schools based solely on standardized test scores. What changes in teaching behavior might emerge, and how could this affect overall educational outcomes?
In a forest ecosystem, how does the removal of a keystone predator like wolves create cascading effects through multiple trophic levels?
A city experiences rapid population growth. Identify three interconnected systems (e.g., housing, transportation, infrastructure) that would be affected and describe the relationships between them.
In a just-in-time manufacturing system, what happens to the entire production line when one supplier experiences a one-week delay, and how does this demonstrate system vulnerability?
How might a carbon tax intended to reduce emissions create both reinforcing and balancing feedback loops in an industrial economy?
A hospital measures doctor performance based on patient satisfaction scores. What behavioral changes might this incentivize, and how could it affect healthcare quality?
In a financial market, how do automated trading algorithms that react to each other's behaviors potentially create emergent patterns that weren't programmed into any individual algorithm?
A city builds more highways to reduce traffic congestion. Explain the concept of 'induced demand' and how it demonstrates that this solution might be ineffective in the long term.
In an office environment, if meeting attendance becomes the primary metric for evaluating employee engagement, what system-wide behaviors might emerge that could reduce actual productivity?
A community relies heavily on groundwater. Identify the key stocks and flows in this system, and explain how a drought might affect the resilience of this system.

In an electrical grid with increasing renewable energy sources, what systematic challenges emerge due to the intermittent nature of wind and solar power, and what buffers might address these challenges?
How does the introduction of a non-native predator to an island ecosystem demonstrate the principle of unintended consequences in complex systems?
A company implements a strict cost-cutting policy across all departments. How might this create tensions between short-term financial goals and long-term growth objectives?
In a social welfare system, what potential feedback loops might emerge from implementing or removing universal basic income?
How do vaccine hesitancy and herd immunity interact as opposing forces in an epidemic control system?
A streaming music service offers artists payment based solely on number of plays. How might this payment system affect musical diversity and artist behavior over time?
In a watershed management system, how do upstream pollution sources create cumulative effects downstream, and why might this create challenges for governance?
A restaurant chain centralizes all purchasing decisions to maximize efficiency. What information flows might be lost in this system, and how could it affect local customer satisfaction?
How does the urban heat island effect demonstrate complex interactions between built environments, climate systems, and human behavior?
In a public transit system, how does a 50% fare reduction potentially create both virtuous and vicious cycles affecting ridership, revenue, and service quality?
A fishing community imposes strict quotas on commercial fishing. Describe how this intervention might affect the marine ecosystem, local economy, and fishing practices over different time scales.
In a housing market, what feedback loops can lead to price bubbles, and what systemic indicators might suggest a bubble is forming?
How does the principle of requisite variety suggest that environmental regulation systems need to match the complexity of the industries they regulate?
A university decides to prioritize research output in faculty evaluations. How might this change the balance between teaching quality and research productivity throughout the institution?
In a social media ecosystem, how do algorithmic recommendations create filter bubbles, and what system-level interventions might counteract this tendency?
An airline rewards pilots for on-time departures. What potential safety implications might emerge from this incentive structure, and what balancing metrics would create a more robust system?
How might increasing automation in manufacturing create ripple effects through employment, education, and social support systems in a regional economy?
In an emergency response system, what communication pathways and decision hierarchies would make the system most resilient to unexpected crisis scenarios?
A retail platform gives preference to products with the highest ratings. What gaming behaviors might emerge from sellers, and how could these distort the information value of the rating system?
In a river ecosystem, how do dams create both upstream and downstream effects that propagate through biological, hydrological, and human systems?
A company introduces a 'zero-defect' quality policy with penalties for errors. What effects might this have on innovation, reporting, and organizational learning?
How does the 'bullwhip effect' in supply chains demonstrate how small changes in consumer demand can create amplified fluctuations upstream in manufacturing and resource extraction?
In a public health system, what interconnected factors might explain why increasing hospital capacity alone might not improve overall population health outcomes?
A city implements rent control to keep housing affordable. What second and third-order effects might emerge in housing quality, development, and neighborhood demographics?
How do composting systems demonstrate circular economy principles, and what feedback loops make them self-regulating if properly designed?
In a democratic political system, what feedback mechanisms exist between public opinion, policy creation, and electoral outcomes? Identify one reinforcing and one balancing loop.
A video streaming platform optimizes for 'time spent watching.' How might this metric create content evolution over time that differs from a platform optimizing for 'viewer satisfaction'?
In a coral reef ecosystem, explain how ocean acidification creates cascading effects through multiple species interactions and feedback loops.
A project management team focuses exclusively on meeting deadlines. What aspects of project health might be neglected in this approach, and what balanced scorecard would better reflect system health?
In a telecommunications network experiencing congestion, why might adding more capacity not solve the problem long-term? What demand-side interventions could create more system resilience?
How does the introduction of autonomous vehicles potentially change the relationships between transportation, urban planning, and energy systems in a city?

A charitable organization measures success by percentage of donations spent directly on program activities rather than administration. What organizational behaviors might this incentivize, and how could it affect long-term impact?
In a waste management system, what interconnected changes would be needed across manufacturing, retail, consumer behavior, and disposal infrastructure to significantly reduce landfill use?
How does the spread of misinformation through social networks demonstrate properties of complex adaptive systems, including emergence and self-organization?
A community uses groundwater for agriculture and drinking water. What signals might indicate that the system is approaching a critical threshold beyond which the aquifer cannot recover?
In a software platform ecosystem, how does the relationship between core platform features and third-party applications create both innovation opportunities and system vulnerabilities?
A healthcare insurer rewards doctors for minimizing costs per patient. What potential conflicts arise between this incentive and optimal patient care, and how might the system be redesigned?
How does a traffic jam demonstrate emergent behavior in a complex system, and why are they difficult to predict at the individual vehicle level?
In an educational system transitioning to personalized learning, what infrastructure elements besides technology need to change for the system transformation to be successful?

A cryptocurrency creates financial incentives for 'mining' operations. What environmental and energy system impacts might emerge at scale, and how do these represent externalities of the system design?
In the global climate system, what makes tipping points particularly concerning from a systems perspective, and why are they difficult to address with incremental policies?

A food delivery app prioritizes delivery speed as its key metric. How might this affect restaurant operations, food quality, and driver behavior in ways that weren't intended by the platform designers?
In a networked electricity grid with distributed generation, what new vulnerabilities and strengths emerge compared to a centralized power generation system?
A government implements a child benefit payment to reduce poverty. Beyond immediate financial impacts, what social and economic feedback loops might develop over a 10-year period?
How does the concept of antifragility suggest that some systems don't merely withstand stressors but actually improve because of them? Give an example of an antifragile system.
In an urban transportation system, how might the introduction of electric scooters create both complementary and competitive relationships with existing modes of transport?
A product development organization measures engineers by lines of code written. What system behaviors might emerge, and how does this metric potentially misalign with creating quality software?
How do invasive species demonstrate the principle that complex systems often have counterintuitive responses to interventions when we don't understand the full web of relationships?
In a social service system helping homeless individuals, what factors beyond housing availability affect outcomes, and how do these factors interact with each other?
A national economy shifts from manufacturing to service industries. What structural adjustments occur across educational systems, regional development, and international trade relationships?
How does the 'tragedy of the commons' demonstrate system behavior that emerges from the interaction of rational individual decisions that collectively lead to suboptimal outcomes?
In a hospital emergency department, what ripple effects throughout the entire hospital system might be caused by a policy requiring all patients to be moved from the ED within 4 hours?
A ride-sharing platform uses surge pricing during high demand. How does this mechanism attempt to create system balance, and what potential unintended consequences might it have on driver behavior?
In a workplace implementing flexible remote work policies, what communication and collaboration systems need to adapt, and how might power dynamics shift within the organization?
How does the human immune system demonstrate properties of complex adaptive systems including memory, learning, and proportional response?
A city wants to reduce crime rates. Comparing a systems approach versus a linear approach, what different interventions might each perspective suggest?

In a competitive marketplace, how do the decisions of multiple companies responding to each other's actions sometimes lead to market outcomes that none of the individual companies intended or desired?
An airline prioritizes maximizing aircraft utilization. How might this create both efficiencies and vulnerabilities in the overall flight network when disruptions occur?
In a community attempting to address adolescent substance abuse, what systems (family, education, healthcare, law enforcement) need to be aligned, and what happens when they work at cross-purposes?
How do ocean currents demonstrate properties of complex systems including energy transfer, feedback loops, and global influence from local conditions?

A government implements a policy offering tax credits for home insulation to reduce energy use. Beyond direct energy savings, what second and third-order effects might emerge in construction, health, and property markets?
In a team-based work environment, how do individual incentives and team-based incentives potentially create different system behaviors, and when might they conflict?
How does the development of antibiotic resistance demonstrate the adaptive nature of complex systems and the challenges of maintaining effectiveness of interventions over time?

A new technology promises to make carbon capture economically viable. From a systems perspective, what questions should be asked about energy inputs, waste products, and scale before assuming this will benefit climate goals?
In a healthcare system, how do prevention, treatment, and palliative care subsystems interact, and what happens when funding heavily favors one component over others?
How do urban food deserts demonstrate the interconnection between transportation systems, economic development, and public health outcomes?
A dating app optimizes for number of matches rather than relationship formation. How might this design choice affect user behavior and satisfaction with the platform over time?
In an agricultural system transitioning to regenerative practices, what time delays might occur between implementation and observable results, and how do these delays affect farmer adoption?
How might the introduction of congestion pricing in a city center create different effects for various stakeholders (commuters, businesses, residents, tourists) over different time horizons?
